title: Rearrange the Equation
text: What should be the first step when completing the square in a quadratic equation like $$x^2-3x-5=0$$?

title: Rearrange the Equation
text: Move the constant term to the other side of the equation.

title: Find the Term to Complete the Square
text: How do you determine what term to add to both sides to complete the square of $$x^2-3x$$?

title: Find the Term to Complete the Square
text: Take half of the coefficient of $$x$$, square it, and add it to both sides. What is half of $$-3$$ squared?

title: Add and Simplify
text: Once you know the term to complete the square, what does the equation look like after adding it to both sides?

title: Add and Simplify
text: Add $${\left(\frac{3}{2}\right)}^2$$ to both sides: $$x^2-3x+\frac{9}{4}=5+\frac{9}{4}$$. Simplify the equation.

title: Solve for $$x$$
text: We need to take the square root of both sides now. What will this reveal?

title: Solve for $$x$$
text: Taking the square root gives you $$x-\frac{3}{2}=\frac{\sqrt{29}}{2}$$ or $$x-\frac{3}{2}=\frac{-\sqrt{29}}{2}$$. Solve for $$x$$ in each case. Please enter your answer in the form a, $$b$$ with "a" being the root that adds within the quadratic equation and "b" being the subtraction. Please include a space after the comma.

title: Final Answer
text: Given that the square roots have been solved, what are the solutions to the original equation?
